Recipe.Name: Kolhapuri Tambda Rassa

Procedure.string: Put the lamb and turmeric in a pan, pour in enough water to cover, season with salt and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat and simmer, covered, for 1 hour or until the lamb is tender.

Meanwhile, heat a frying pan over a high heat, add the cumin seeds and dry-toast them until they start to darken. Add the sesame seeds and coconut, then when they start to turn golden, tip the toasted spices into a blender along with the ginger-garlic paste and fresh coriander. Pour in enough cold water to just cover the mixture and blitz to form a paste.

Heat the oil in a heavy-based saucepan over a high heat, add the onions and fry for 7-8 minutes until soft. Add the Kolhapuri masala and the contents of the blender, then add 1 tablespoon of water - this will cook the spices without scorching them and encourage the oil to separate at the edges.

Add the cooked meat and stock, bring to the boil and simmer for 4-5 minutes to blend the flavours. Squeeze in the lemon juice and season to taste. The curry should be thin, with the oil ('kat') floating on top. Serve hot with rice.

Notes.string: Make sure your food processor can adequately puree the cilantro otherwise you will end up with a bunch of gritty chunks

Ingredient.Name: lamb on the bone
Ingredient.WholeLine: 800 g lamb on the bone, diced

Ingredient.Name: of fresh coriander leaves
Ingredient.WholeLine: a SmallHandful of fresh coriander leaves

Ingredient.Name: kolhapuri masala - or a mix of 1 tablespoon garam masala with 1 teaspoon medium-hot red chilli powder and 1 teaspoon crushed black pepper
Ingredient.WholeLine: 3 tablespoons kolhapuri masala - or a mix of 1 tablespoon garam masala with 1 teaspoon medium-hot red chilli powder and 1 teaspoon crushed black pepper

CookInstance.Notes: Did not turn out great. Came out as a green gritty paste. Hypothesis for this include not using proper kolhapuri masala, used to much cilantro, and ninja did not puree cilantro well enough. Used pork instead and it got overcooked in the boil, probably stick with lamb for this one.

Recipe.Description: Kolhapur in Maharashtra is known for its spicy, rich meat and chicken curries flavoured with small, hot 'lavangi' chillies and Kolhapuri masala, a bright red spice blend. Sankeshawr also provides chillies for Kolhapuri curries and these are fiery red, too!
